page.title: 01FOUR MARKS: ITS NAME
page.content: HOW FOUR MARKS GOT ITS NAME: At the time of the Napoleonic wars( early 1800's), a line of beacons was maintained (before Semaphore) from Portsmouth to London. A fee was payable for maintaining the beacon and the site at Telegraph Lane was claimed by the four parishes of Chawton, Medstead, Farringdon and Ropley. The Bishop of Winchester decided that the Beacon Area would be designated as extra-parochial and bounded by Four Stone Marks and he would take the fee for maintaining the Beacon. Hence, Four Marks was originally the area of the Beacon site. The name appears on the 1897 Ordnance map and a Post Office Guide for 1875 lists a public house in Medstead called 'The Four Marks' run by a John Wyeth. In 1904 Four Marks was using its own cancellation on letters.
